The prompter rings the lofty curtain down,</br>The gaping audience leave the pit with glee,</br>Homeward in troops return the weary town,</br>And leave the house to emptiness and me.
Now fades each glimmering candle on the sight,</br>And thro' the air a smoky silence reigns,</br>Save where some lobby hero seeks the fight,</br>And bravely gets a beating for his pains;
Save that to scare Piazza-haunting flocks,</br>The moping watchman does in oaths complain,</br>Of such as, wandering near his secret box,</br>With clamour loud intrude on his domain.
Their parts perform'd, behind the curtain's shade</br>Where stretch the scenes in many a motley heap,</br>Each in his humble lodging quiet laid,</br>The chorus-singing tribe securely sleep.
The summons of rehearsal bringing morn,</br>The prompter whispering from his wooden shed,</br>The trumpet, hautboy, clarinet, and horn</br>Shall rouse each man to-morrow from his bed.
And yet for them no opera pours its rhyme;</br>No loud encore rewards their evening care;</br>No children run to hail their pantomime,</br>Or crowd the box, the envied laugh to share.
As sailors oft they hail'd Britannia's shore;</br>As forty thieves they spurn'd the sultan's yoke;</br>Their shoulders oft Peruvian Rolla bore;</br>How bow'd their heads when mighty Bluebeard spoke!
Let not tragedians mock their useful toil,</br>Their russet boots, by hundreds worn before;</br>Nor Fashion hear, with a disdainful smile,</br>The lowly annals of our Thespian corps.
The dice of Beverley, the straw of Lear,</br>And all that Hamlet, all Macbeth e'er gave,</br>In the fifth act conclude their high career—</br>For tragic glory leads but to the grave.
Nor you, rich actors, lay on these the blame,</br>If their poor names no daily journals raise,</br>Where, thro' the long-drawn column, bent on fame,</br>The editor resounds the note of praise.
Can studied puffs an actor's fame decide,</br>Or to a throne a mute attendant carry?</br>Can praise give pow'rs that nature has denied,</br>Or make Beau Clincher equal to Sir Harry?
Perhaps in these neglected ranks has stray'd</br>Some swelling bosom, fraught with tragic fire;</br>Tongues that Othello's vengeance might have stay'd,</br>Or base Iago prov'd a living liar!
But authors to their eyes their ample plays,</br>Rich in fine acting parts, did never bring;</br>The manager repress'd their mental blaze,</br>And pent them up in choruses to sing.
Of sonnetteers full many a rhyming moan</br>The monthly magazines, unread, contain;</br>Full many a joke is cut, to die unknown,</br>Lost in the echoing dome of Drury-Lane.
Some unknown Garrick, with adventurous wing,</br>Clipp'd by the shears of want and melancholy;</br>Some low inglorious Braham here may sing,</br>Some Betty, guiltless of a nation's folly!
Th' applause of wondering boxes to attract,</br>Their face engrav'd in public shops to boast,</br>T' ensure a full box-book whene'er they act,</br>And read their history in the Morning Post,
Their lot forbad:  nor circumscrib'd alone</br>Their growing talents, but their faults unseen:</br>T' omit the author's jest, insert their own,</br>Or woo the boxes while they slight the scene.
By mummery the writer's text to hide,</br>Their influence o'er the galleries to boast,</br>Or mar the play, and decency deride,</br>With nonsense purchas'd at the Muse's cost.
Far from the rattling squares and Fashion's sport,</br>Their small finances rather bade them stay</br>In Russell Street, Long Acre, Martlet Court;</br>Convenient spots contiguous to the play!
Yet e'en these names from Lethe to protect,</br>Some lengthen'd play-bill still erected there,</br>With letters of all sorts and sizes deck'd,</br>Implores the passing tribute of a stare!
Their names, their characters, a motley pack;</br>Great heroes first, and mute attendants last:</br>Robbers and senators, in red and black,</br>To shew the public how the parts are cast.
For who, to careless nonchalance a prey,</br>Of self-importance never gave one hint—</br>Pass'd idly by the red bills of the day,</br>Nor cast one look to see himself in print?
Ambition on our mimic stage will rise;</br>Trueman survives, when Barnwell yields his breath;</br>Emilia raves, when Desdemona dies;</br>The bleeding captain emulates Macbeth.
For thee, who mindful of thy brethren dead,</br>Dost in these lines their useful toils relate,</br>If chance, by curiosity misled,</br>Some gentler critic shall enquire thy fate.
Haply the leader of the band may say,</br>"Oft have I seen him, standing there aloof,</br>Eager to write, as well as act, a play,</br>And wooing Phoebus frowning on the roof.
"Fronting the audience, in a double mood,</br>Muttering his dialogue, now brisk, now sad:</br>Sometimes, as actor, tolerably good,</br>Always, as bard, intolerably bad.

"One night they hiss'd him in the accustom'd scene—</br>I thought the play was damn'd — 'ah, woe is me,'</br>Another came, with scarce a pause between,</br>They hiss'd again — in doleful plight was he!
"The third, with dirges due, in sad array,</br>The prompter's sheep-bell rang our poet's knell,</br>Approach and read (none else will read) the play,</br>If not — the epilogue may do as well."
THE EPILOGUE.</br>Here rests his head upon the prompter's shelf,</br>A bard to wisdom and to wit unknown;</br>Thalia smil'd not on the scribbling elf,</br>But gentle dulness mark'd him for her own.
Coy from his suit the Muses turn'd away,</br>A Day in London ill his toil requites;</br>He gave the town — 'twas all he had — a play;</br>The town denied — his only wish — nine nights!
No further seek his writings to deride,</br>Nor try to mend what sentiment has marr'd:</br>Oblivion's veil his comedy shall hide,</br>And shroud in night the actor and the bard!</br>
